div.p: We provide a model independent criterion which would guarantee a large flavor mixing of two quasi-degenerate Majorana neutrinos at the low scale, irrespective of the mixing at the high scale. We also show that such a situation is realizable for a phenomenologically interesting range of parameters of the weak scale theory. We further claim that for a similar condition to be implementable for the three generation case, the Câ¢Pğ¶ğ‘ƒitalic-C italic-PCP parity of one of the neutrinos needs to be opposite to that of the others.

p.span: Generation of large flavor mixing from radiative corrections
Institute of Mathematical Sciences, Chennai 600 113, India.
Div. TH, CERN, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland.
Department of Physics, University of Maryland, College park MD 20742, USA.
Department of Physics, North Eastern Hill University, Shillong 793022, India.

div.p: PACS numbers: 12.15.Lk, 14.60.Pq, 12.60.-i

The observed atmospheric and solar neutrino anomalies from the terrestrial experiments [1, 2] seem to provide a strong evidence in favor of neutrino flavor conversions, implying that neutrinos are massive and they mix among themselves. While the details are fuzzy at this stage, it is clear that the atmospheric neutrino data require a large mixing of Î½Î¼â†”Î½Ï„â†”subscriptğœˆğœ‡subscriptğœˆğœitalic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end METARELOP:leftrightarrow italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{\mu}\leftrightarrow
u_{	au} or Î½Î¼â†”Î½sâ†”subscriptğœˆğœ‡subscriptğœˆğ‘ italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end METARELOP:leftrightarrow italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{\mu}\leftrightarrow
u_{s}, although the latter possibility is beginning to look less and less likely [3]. Regarding the solar neutrino anomaly, the mixing angle (between Î½esubscriptğœˆğ‘’italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{e} and Î½Î¼,Ï„subscriptğœˆğœ‡ğœitalic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu PUNCT:, italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{\mu,	au} or Î½ssubscriptğœˆğ‘ italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{s}) could be small, as in the small angle MSW scenario, or large, as in the large angle MSW or vacuum oscillation scenarios [2].

Since large mixing angles are involved in the possible solutions of both the anomalies, a great deal of theoretical work has gone in the understanding of the maximal mixing [4]. There are two complementary approaches: (i) searching for scenarios and symmetries beyond the standard model, and (ii) establishing general model independent criteria which guarantee the stability at the weak scale of the masses and mixing pattern that emerge at the high scale. The second approach has the advantage that it may not only narrow down the search for new physics scenarios to a manageable level, but it may also throw light on the parameters of the theory at the high scale, and on the value of the high scale itself. In this paper, we present some model independent criteria for such theories, first focussing on the two flavor case and subsequently on the three flavor models.

If neutrinos contribute even a small fraction of the dark matter [5] of the universe, the oscillation observations imply a situation where at least two neutrinos (and possibly even three) are quasi-degenerate in mass. If the neutrino mass hierarchy is inverted (m3<m1,m2subscriptğ‘š3subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{3}<m_{1},m_{2} where |Î”â¢m322|â‰«|Î”â¢m212|much-greater-thanÎ”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘š232Î”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘š221VERTBAR:| Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:32 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:much-greater-than VERTBAR:| Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:21 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:||\Delta m^{2}_{32}|\gg|\Delta m^{2}_{21}|), the neutrinos Î½1subscriptğœˆ1italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\nu_{1} and Î½2subscriptğœˆ2italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\nu_{2} are necessarily quasi-degenerate. The study of scenarios where two or even three neutrinos are nearly degenerate is therefore of crucial importance.

The two flavor quasi-degenerate neutrino scenarios fall in two classes: the neutrino flavors in the degenerate limit can be (i) in the same Câ¢Pğ¶ğ‘ƒitalic-C italic-PCP eigenstate or (ii) in opposite Câ¢Pğ¶ğ‘ƒitalic-C italic-PCP eigenstates. It turns out that not only does one need to invoke different kinds of symmetries to understand the two cases, but the radiative corrections to the tree level degeneracy at the high scale can have very different implications for the two cases. For instance, it has been noted in [6, 7, 8] that in the case (ii), the radiative corrections (such as those through the RGE evolution from the seesaw to the weak scale) do not substantially affect the maximal mixing and quasi-degeneracy predicted by the theory at a high scale.

In this analysis, we point out that in the case (i), an arbitrary mixing at the high scale can get â€œmagnifiedâ€ to a large mixing, and even possibly maximal mixing, at the low scale. We find this interesting because (a) it enables a model builder to avoid any fine-tuning for the values of mixing angles at the high scale, and hence relaxes the constraints on the parameters of the high scale physics, (b) it brings a certain unity in the understanding of the quark and lepton mixings. This is arrived at by relating the radiative corrections and the degree of mass degeneracy (Î´â¢mmğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘šFRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-delta italic-m ARG:end ARG:start italic-m ARG:end\frac{\delta m}{m}), regardless of the mixing pattern at the high scale. In the context of specific models, this also leads to relationships between the degree of degeneracy, the value of the high scale and the model parameters (e.g. tanâ¡Î²ğ›½TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta for the MSSM). We further extend the results to the three generation scenario and find that the constraint on Ueâ¢3subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘’3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{e3} from the CHOOZ experiment [9] indicates that the Câ¢Pğ¶ğ‘ƒitalic-C italic-PCP parity of one of the neutrinos must be opposite to that of the others for our scheme to be implementable.

Our paper is organized in the following form: in the next section, we derive our main result for the two flavor mixing. In section III, we present implications of the two flavor result for the case of the standard model and the MSSM. In section IV, we consider the extension to three generation case.

section.h2: II BASIC FORMALISM FOR TWO FLAVORS

div.p: Consider the mixing of two neutrinos. The 2Ã—222NUMBER:2 MULOP:times NUMBER:22\times 2 Majorana matrix in the mass basis is of the form

We define the convention for the â€œnumberingâ€ of Î½1subscriptğœˆ1italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

u_{ eta} be the Sâ¢Uâ¢(2)Lğ‘†ğ‘ˆsubscript2ğ¿italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:endSU(2)_{L} partners of the charged leptons â„“Î±subscriptâ„“ğ›¼ell POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\ell_{\alpha} and â„“Î²subscriptâ„“ğ›½ell POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\ell_{ eta} respectively, such that mâ„“Î±<mâ„“Î²subscriptğ‘šsubscriptâ„“ğ›¼subscriptğ‘šsubscriptâ„“ğ›½italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ell POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ell POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{\ell_{\alpha}}<m_{\ell_{ eta}}. Then we define Î½1subscriptğœˆ1italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{1} (Î½2subscriptğœˆ2italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{2}) as the state with a larger component of the flavor Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha (Î²ğ›½italic-beta eta) at the high scale. With this convention, 0â‰¤Î¸â‰¤Ï€/40ğœƒğœ‹4NUMBER:0 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-theta RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:40\leq	heta\leq\pi/4.
The mass matrix in the flavor basis can be written as

OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end CELL:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start ADDOP:minus italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end CELL:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-i italic-phi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end CELL:start ADDOP:minus italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end CELL:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: Let us examine the situation when Ï•=0italic-Ï•0italic-phi RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\phi=0, which corresponds to the case when the neutrinos Î½1subscriptğœˆ1italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\nu_{1} and Î½2subscriptğœˆ2italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\nu_{2} are in the same Câ¢Pğ¶ğ‘ƒitalic-C italic-PCP eigenstate. Due to the presence of radiative corrections to m1subscriptğ‘š1italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{1} and m2subscriptğ‘š2italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{2}, the matrix â„³â„±subscriptâ„³â„±caligraphic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\cal{M_{F}} gets modified to

semantics.annotation: caligraphic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARROW:to OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:caligraphic-1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:caligraphic-0 CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:caligraphic-0 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:caligraphic-1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:) caligraphic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:caligraphic-1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:caligraphic-0 CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:caligraphic-0 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:caligraphic-1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: In the above, Î´Î±subscriptğ›¿ğ›¼italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta_{\alpha} and Î´Î²subscriptğ›¿ğ›½italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta_{\beta} denote the corrections to the masses in the flavor basis. The above general structure for â„³â„±subscriptâ„³â„±caligraphic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\cal M_{F} has been motivated by the RGE structure for radiative corrections [10]. We define

semantics.annotation: italic-epsilon RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:2 OPEN:( italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: which is the net difference in the radiative corrections for the masses of the two neutrino flavors.

The mixing angle Î¸Â¯Â¯ğœƒOVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-theta ARG:end\bar{\theta} that now diagonalizes the matrix â„³â„±subscriptâ„³â„±caligraphic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\cal{M_{F}} at the low scale Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu (after radiative corrections) can be related to the old mixing angle Î¸ğœƒitalic-theta\theta through the following expression:

semantics.annotation: TRIGFUNCTION:tangent NUMBER:2 OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-theta ARG:end RELOP:equals TRIGFUNCTION:tangent NUMBER:2 italic-theta OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-lambda ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where

semantics.annotation: italic-lambda RELOP:equivalent-to FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: In the case of near degeneracy: m1â‰ˆm2â‰ˆmsubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2ğ‘šitalic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals italic-mm_{1}\approx m_{2}\approx m, we have

semantics.annotation: italic-lambda RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-m italic-epsilon ARG:end ARG:start OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 PUNCT:,

div.p: where mğ‘šitalic-mm is the common mass scale of the neutrinos.
If

semantics.annotation: VERTBAR:| italic-m italic-epsilon VERTBAR:| RELOP:much-greater-than VERTBAR:| OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| PUNCT:,

div.p: then Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†italic-lambda ARROW:rightarrow ID:infinity\lambda\rightarrow\infty and we have tanâ¡2â¢Î¸Â¯â†’0â†’2Â¯ğœƒ0TRIGFUNCTION:tangent NUMBER:2 OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-theta ARG:end ARROW:to NUMBER:0\tan 2\bar{\theta}\to 0. Under this condition, any mixing angle tends to zero after radiative corrections, i.e. a large mixing is unstable under radiative corrections. Note that this is true only for the two neutrinos with the same Câ¢Pğ¶ğ‘ƒitalic-C italic-PCP parity. If they had different Câ¢Pğ¶ğ‘ƒitalic-C italic-PCP parities, i.e. Ï•=Ï€italic-Ï•ğœ‹italic-phi RELOP:equals italic-pi\phi=\pi, quasi-degeneracy would imply |m1|â‰ˆ|m2|â‰ˆmsubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2ğ‘šVERTBAR:| italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:approximately-equals VERTBAR:| italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:approximately-equals italic-m|m_{1}|\approx|m_{2}|\approx m, however |m1-m2|â‰ˆ2â¢msubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š22ğ‘šVERTBAR:| italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:2 italic-m|m_{1}-m_{2}|\approx 2m. Then the radiative corrections (which are small) cannot give the inequality (10). In this case, |mâ¢Ïµ|â‰ª|(m2-m1)â¢C2â¢Î¸|much-less-thanğ‘šitalic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ¶2ğœƒVERTBAR:| italic-m italic-epsilon VERTBAR:| RELOP:much-less-than VERTBAR:| OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:||m\epsilon|\ll|(m_{2}-m_{1})C_{2\theta}|, so that Î»â‰ˆ1ğœ†1italic-lambda RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1\lambda\approx 1 and the mixing angle does not change much. The mixing at the high scale then remains stable. This reproduces the observations made in [6, 7] regarding the stability of the Maki-Nakagawa-Sakata (MNS) mixing matrix [11], when the mixing angle is close to Ï€/4ğœ‹4italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\pi/4. In addition, our analysis shows that the same conclusions remain valid for any arbitrary nonzero Î¸ğœƒitalic-theta\theta of the MNS matrix.
If

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: then Î»=0ğœ†0italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\lambda=0 or equivalently Î¸Â¯=Ï€/4Â¯ğœƒğœ‹4OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-theta ARG:end RELOP:equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\bar{\theta}=\pi/4; i.e. maximal mixing. Given the mass heirarchy of the charged leptons: mlÎ±â‰ªmlÎ²much-less-thansubscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ‘™ğ›¼subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ‘™ğ›½italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:much-less-than italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{l_{\alpha}}\ll m_{l_{\beta}}, we expect |Î´Î±|â‰ª|Î´Î²|much-less-thansubscriptğ›¿ğ›¼subscriptğ›¿ğ›½VERTBAR:| italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:much-less-than VERTBAR:| italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:||\delta_{\alpha}|\ll|\delta_{\beta}|, which reduces (11) to a simpler form:

semantics.annotation: italic-epsilon RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-delta italic-m italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where Î´â¢mâ‰¡m1-m2ğ›¿ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2italic-delta italic-m RELOP:equivalent-to italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta m\equiv m_{1}-m_{2}. In the quasi-degenerate case,

semantics.annotation: italic-epsilon RELOP:approximately-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-delta italic-m ARG:end ARG:start italic-m ARG:end italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.

div.p: The above expression can be translated in terms of the mass-squared difference (which is the quantity measured in the oscillation experiments) as

semantics.annotation: italic-epsilon RELOP:approximately-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( Lambda CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where Î”â¢m2â¢(Î›)=m12â¢(Î›)-m22â¢(Î›)Î”superscriptğ‘š2Î›superscriptsubscriptğ‘š12Î›superscriptsubscriptğ‘š22Î›Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( Lambda CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( Lambda CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( Lambda CLOSE:)\Delta m^{2}(\Lambda)~{}=~{}m_{1}^{2}(\Lambda)-m_{2}^{2}(\Lambda). If the condition (14) is satisfied, the mixing at the scale Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu tends to become maximal regardless of the value of the mixing at the scale Î›Î›Lambda\Lambda.

Several points are worth emphasizing here.
1. The above relation between Ïµitalic-Ïµitalic-epsilon\epsilon and the neutrino parameters Î¸ğœƒitalic-theta\theta, m1subscriptğ‘š1italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{1} and m2subscriptğ‘š2italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{2} is a model independent result and has profound implications for model building. For instance, it will relax the domain of parameters of the high scale theory compared to what was believed earlier for Ï•=0italic-Ï•0italic-phi RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\phi=0.
2. From (14), the sign of Ïµitalic-Ïµitalic-epsilon\epsilon must be the same as that of Î”â¢m2â¢(Î›)Î”superscriptğ‘š2Î›Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( Lambda CLOSE:)\Delta m^{2}(\Lambda) for getting maximal mixing at the low scale. This preference is of a phenomenological importance since the sign of Î”â¢m2Î”superscriptğ‘š2Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta m^{2} at low scales is measured by experiments: if the solar neutrino solution is MSW, the identity of the heavier neutrino is known, and the heavy / light nature of the third neutrino may be determined through the long baseline experiments [12] or the observations of a galactic supernova [13]. The model needs to be able to reproduce this sign from the values of the masses at the high scale through the RGE. The results of this paper can thus be used to discriminate between various models for a large flavor mixing.
3. The condition (14) is not to be mistaken for a fine-tuning. Though maximal mixing at the low scale requires an exact equality (14), the condition can be slackened if we only need a large mixing. Indeed, the SK data [1] indicate |tanâ¡2â¢Î¸Â¯|>22Â¯ğœƒ2VERTBAR:| TRIGFUNCTION:tangent NUMBER:2 OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-theta ARG:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:2|\tan 2\bar{\theta}|>2 at 90% c.l.. In Fig. 1, we show the range of Ïµitalic-Ïµitalic-epsilon\epsilon that allows a large mixing at the scale Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu as a function of the mixing angle at the scale Î›Î›Lambda\Lambda. The region enclosed within the â€œleafâ€ gives the range of Ïµitalic-Ïµitalic-epsilon\epsilon which generates a large mixing (|tanâ¡2â¢Î¸Â¯|>22Â¯ğœƒ2VERTBAR:| TRIGFUNCTION:tangent NUMBER:2 OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-theta ARG:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:2|\tan 2\bar{\theta}|>2). The value of the degree of degeneracy |Î´â¢mm|ğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘šVERTBAR:| FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-delta italic-m ARG:end ARG:start italic-m ARG:end VERTBAR:||\frac{\delta m}{m}| chosen for the figure is 0.1. From (13), changing this value would just change the scale of Ïµitalic-Ïµitalic-epsilon\epsilon by a factor proportional to |Î´â¢mm|ğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘šVERTBAR:| FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-delta italic-m ARG:end ARG:start italic-m ARG:end VERTBAR:||\frac{\delta m}{m}|. The figure shows that a large mixing at the scale Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu is indeed possible for a large range of neutrino parameters. The condition on the signs of Ïµitalic-Ïµitalic-epsilon\epsilon and Î”â¢m2Î”superscriptğ‘š2Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta m^{2} is also relaxed if the mixing at the high scale is already large.

section.h2: III APPLICATIONS TO THE STANDARD MODEL AND THE MSSM

div.p: In this section, we analyze the implications of (14) for the case of the standard model (SM) and MSSM to see whether it is satisfied for acceptable values of the model parameters. In the case of the SM, the value of ÏµSâ¢Msubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘†ğ‘€italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{SM} from the RGE evolution is

semantics.annotation: italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:32 italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end italic-l italic-n OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start Lambda ARG:end ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: where hÎ²subscriptâ„ğ›½italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{\beta} corresponds to the Yukawa coupling of the heavier charged lepton. Eq. (13) and the sign of ÏµSâ¢Msubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘†ğ‘€italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{SM} in (15) imply that for large flavor mixing to be generated in the SM through radiative corrections, we require m1>m2subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{1}>m_{2}. In addition, from (14) and (15), the strength of hÎ²subscriptâ„ğ›½italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{\beta} needs to be

semantics.annotation: italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-S italic-M CLOSE:) RELOP:approximately-equals italic-square-root ARG:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:16 italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( Lambda CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-l italic-n OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start Lambda ARG:end ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: This is a relation between Î”â¢m2â¢(Î›)Î”superscriptğ‘š2Î›Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( Lambda CLOSE:)\Delta m^{2}(\Lambda) and the scale Î›Î›Lambda\Lambda that needs to be obeyed. As an illustration, taking Î²â‰¡Î¼ğ›½ğœ‡italic-beta RELOP:equivalent-to italic-mu\beta\equiv\mu (for Î½eâ†”Î½Î¼â†”subscriptğœˆğ‘’subscriptğœˆğœ‡italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end METARELOP:leftrightarrow italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\nu_{e}\leftrightarrow\nu_{\mu}, for example), with hÎ¼â‰ˆ6Ã—10-4subscriptâ„ğœ‡6superscript104italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:6 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endh_{\mu}\approx 6\times 10^{-4} and the high scale as Î›âˆ¼1012similar-toÎ›superscript1012Lambda RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Lambda\sim 10^{12} GeV, for degenerate neutrino mass of mâˆ¼1similar-toğ‘š1italic-m RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1m\sim 1 eV, we get |Î”â¢m2â¢(Î›)|â‰ˆ10-7Î”superscriptğ‘š2Î›superscript107VERTBAR:| Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( Lambda CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:7 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end|\Delta m^{2}(\Lambda)|\approx 10^{-7} eV22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}.
In the case of MSSM, we have

semantics.annotation: italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-M italic-S italic-S italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:16 italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end italic-l italic-n OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start Lambda ARG:end ARG:start italic-mu ARG:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: Eq. (13) and the sign of ÏµMâ¢Sâ¢Sâ¢Msubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘€ğ‘†ğ‘†ğ‘€italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-M italic-S italic-S italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{MSSM} in (17) imply that we need m1<m2subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{1}<m_{2} for large flavor mixing to be generated through radiative corrections in the MSSM. In addition, from (14) and (17), the strength of hÎ²subscriptâ„ğ›½italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{\beta} has to be of the order of

semantics.annotation: italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M italic-S italic-S italic-M CLOSE:) RELOP:approximately-equals italic-square-root ARG:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:8 italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( Lambda CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-l italic-n OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start Lambda ARG:end ARG:start italic-mu ARG:end CLOSE:) italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: Taking Î²â‰¡Ï„ğ›½ğœitalic-beta RELOP:equivalent-to italic-tau\beta\equiv\tau (for Î½Î¼â†”Î½Ï„â†”subscriptğœˆğœ‡subscriptğœˆğœitalic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end METARELOP:leftrightarrow italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\nu_{\mu}\leftrightarrow\nu_{\tau} mixing, for example), and using

semantics.annotation: italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-v TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-beta ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: we get a relation between Î›Î›Lambda\Lambda, tanâ¡Î²ğ›½TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta and mğ‘šitalic-mm, the common mass scale of the neutrinos. In Fig. 2 we show the variation of Ïµitalic-Ïµitalic-epsilon\epsilon with Î›Î›Lambda\Lambda in MSSM for different values of hÏ„subscriptâ„ğœitalic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{\tau}. From (18) and (19), for given mğ‘šitalic-mm and Î›Î›Lambda\Lambda, we can infer the desirable value of hÏ„subscriptâ„ğœitalic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{\tau} and hence of tanâ¡Î²ğ›½TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta. For example, for mâˆ¼1â¢eâ¢Vsimilar-toğ‘š1ğ‘’ğ‘‰italic-m RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 italic-e italic-Vm\sim 1eV and Î›âˆ¼1012â¢Gâ¢eâ¢Vsimilar-toÎ›superscript1012ğºğ‘’ğ‘‰Lambda RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-G italic-e italic-V\Lambda\sim 10^{12}GeV, taking |Î”â¢m2â¢(Î›)|â‰ˆ10-3â¢eâ¢V2Î”superscriptğ‘š2Î›superscript103ğ‘’superscriptğ‘‰2VERTBAR:| Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( Lambda CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end|\Delta m^{2}(\Lambda)|\approx 10^{-3}eV^{2}, we get tanâ¡Î²â‰ˆ5ğ›½5TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:5\tan\beta\approx 5.

Let us now make a few comments on the possible extension to the case of three quasi-degenerate Majorana neutrinos. If mÎ±â¢Î²subscriptğ‘šğ›¼ğ›½italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{\alpha\beta} are the elements of the neutrino mass matrix in the flavor basis, then in the approximation of the decoupling of the third flavor, a large mixing between flavors Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha and Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta is guaranteed at the low scale if

semantics.annotation: italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:2 OPEN:( italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:approximately-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where no summation over repeated indices is implied. Assuming that the Î”â¢m2Î”superscriptğ‘š2Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta m^{2} hierarchy observed at the low scale is true at the high scale also (small radiative corrections), we have |m1-m2|â‰ª|m2-m3|much-less-thansubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘š3VERTBAR:| italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:much-less-than VERTBAR:| italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:||m_{1}-m_{2}|\ll|m_{2}-m_{3}|. The condition for UÎ¼â¢3subscriptğ‘ˆğœ‡3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{\mu 3} to be maximal is then

semantics.annotation: italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( VERTBAR:| italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus VERTBAR:| italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-m ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: In all the models in which hÏ„subscriptâ„ğœitalic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{\tau} dominates over hesubscriptâ„ğ‘’italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{e} and hÎ¼subscriptâ„ğœ‡italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{\mu}, we have Ïµeâ¢Ï„â‰ˆÏµÎ¼â¢Ï„subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘’ğœsubscriptitalic-Ïµğœ‡ğœitalic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{e\tau}\approx\epsilon_{\mu\tau}. Then, the condition for the enhancement of UÎ¼â¢3subscriptğ‘ˆğœ‡3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{\mu 3} (21) is similar to the condition for the enhancement of Ueâ¢3subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘’3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{e3} (with the replacement [Î¼â†’e,2â†’1]delimited-[]formulae-sequenceâ†’ğœ‡ğ‘’â†’21OPEN:[ italic-mu ARROW:to italic-e PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 ARROW:to NUMBER:1 CLOSE:][\mu\to e,2\to 1]) if all the neutrinos have the same Câ¢Pğ¶ğ‘ƒitalic-C italic-PCP parity, assuming that both UÏ„â¢1,UÏ„â¢2â‰ªUÏ„â¢3much-less-thansubscriptğ‘ˆğœ1subscriptğ‘ˆğœ2subscriptğ‘ˆğœ3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:much-less-than italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{\tau 1},U_{\tau 2}\ll U_{\tau 3}. That would imply that when UÎ¼â¢3subscriptğ‘ˆğœ‡3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{\mu 3} is magnified due to radiative corrections, so is Ueâ¢3subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘’3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{e3}. Then one cannot naturally get a small value of Ueâ¢3subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘’3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{e3} at the low scale, as is suggested by the CHOOZ data [9]. Thus, in the three generation case with quasi-degenerate Majorana neutrinos, we need the Câ¢Pğ¶ğ‘ƒitalic-C italic-PCP phase of one neutrino opposite to that of the other two in order for our condition to be implementable. It should be noted that satisfying this condition still does not guarantee the stability of small Ueâ¢3subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘’3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{e3}.

In conclusion, we have derived a model independent condition that guarantees a large mixing at the low scale irrespective of the mixing angle at the high scale, for two quasi-degenerate Majorana neutrinos with the same Câ¢Pğ¶ğ‘ƒitalic-C italic-PCP parity. The condition relates the masses at the high scale to the radiative corrections. In the case of SM and MSSM, this predicts the sign of the mass difference between the neutrinos and also gives a range for its magnitude. In MSSM, it translates into a relation between the value of the high scale Î›Î›Lambda\Lambda, tanâ¡Î²ğ›½TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta, and the common mass of the neutrinos. Extending the argument to three quasi-degenerate Majorana neutrinos, we again show in a model independent way that the CP parity of one of the neutrinos should be opposite to that of the others for our conditions to be implementable at the phenomenological level.

We thank WHEPP-6, Chennai, India, where a part of the work was completed. The work of RNM is supported by the NSF Grant no. PHY-9802551. The work of MKP is supproted by the project No. 98/37/9/BRNS-cell/731 of the Govt. of India.

Here Ï‡â‰¡Î¸ğœ’ğœƒitalic-chi RELOP:equivalent-to italic-theta\chi\equiv\theta for m1<m2subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{1}<m_{2} and Ï‡â‰¡Ï€2-Î¸ğœ’ğœ‹2ğœƒitalic-chi RELOP:equivalent-to FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-pi ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ADDOP:minus italic-theta\chi\equiv\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta for m1>m2subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{1}>m_{2}.
